awd_titl_txt: US Government Support for IAI Core Budget 2018-2023
awd_abstract_narration:
The Inter-American Institute for Global Change Research (IAI) is an international treaty organization, of which the US is a partner. It was created to coordinate and promote scientific research related to global change in the Americas and to build scientific capacity in the region in addition to fostering collaboration and coordination of science on global change across national boundaries. The IAI supports extensive long-term collaborative research networks that increase use of inter- and transdisciplinary research on global change as it impacts the Americas. The Institute also develops training materials for constituents to foster the integration of research across disciplinary and international boundaries. As part of its office functions, the IAI helps support scientist/community/policy maker interactions and the co-design and development of interdisciplinary scientific research projects to help better understand complex problems plaguing nations in the Americas that involve physico-chemical-human-ecosystem related challenges resulting from global change, the solutions of which involve addressing the needs of diverse stakeholders such that the results can be used in the development of effective science-based policies that serve local communities and/or national and regional and/or cross-border interests. In this regard and in response to its governing body of nations from across the Americans that define IAI's agenda for each funding period, the Inter-American Institute for Global Change Research will continue to support its collaborative research network programs and will also analyze and make public best practices for establishing inter- and transdisciplinary, intersectional teams that can tackle problem-focused research.  Broader impacts of the work include the fostering of international collaboration between and among scientists, research groups, and countries across the Americas; creating educational and training materials for effective creation of transdisciplinary scientific research projects that address pressing issues related to global change; encouraging the adoption of open data and data sharing practices; and enabling the production of scientific research results useful to local communities as well as policy- and decision-makers. Other impacts include an aggressive educational program for students and others that includes workshops on science diplomacy and the science-to-policy process. 

The Inter-American Institute for Global Change Research is an office that has an evolving science agenda that is determined, on a regular basis, by its governing body, which is comprised of 19 countries across the Americas. Its science agenda is complementary to the research priorities of the US Global Change Research Program. The award covers IAI Directorate staff salaries and travel costs for administering the office and for interacting with partner states and its research coordination networks. It also covers consultant services; computing, web, and internet services; communications; and part of the IAI publication budget.  IAI activities are also supported by membership fees from each of the countries making up its governing board. The main goals of the organization are to: (1) promote regional cooperation for interdisciplinary research on aspects of global change affecting the Americas; (2) enable regional scale research which cannot be pursued by any individual country or institution; (3) build science capacity and improve the scientific and technical capabilities and research infrastructure of the States in the region; and (4) foster standardization, collection, analysis, and exchange of scientific data between research groups and countries. Over the next five years, IAI will also work to build partnerships with other global change organizations with interests in global change science and policy.  As part of its mission, between 2014 and 2018, IAI helped coordinate 17 multi-country inter- and transdisciplinary global change research collaborations involving over 100 investigators in 90 institutions in 15 partner countries.  Its mission is to assist the scientific community in the region to developing a collaborative way of providing solid scientific understandings of global change issues in support of sustainable development in the region.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Inter-American Institute for Global Change Research (IAI) has demonstrated transformative leadership in fostering scientific collaboration, capacity building, and science-policy integration on global environmental change across the Americas. Supported by the US Government's contribution to its core budget (2019-2024) through the National Science Foundation, the IAI has positioned itself as a key actor at the science-policy-diplomacy nexus, addressing critical regional challenges, such as biodiversity loss and water scarcity, through interdisciplinary and transdisciplinary approaches. 

Strategic Achievements and Intellectual Contributions: 

1. Advancing Transdisciplinary Research: 

   Through science funding programs such as the Small Grants Program, Seed Grants, and Belmont Forum Collaborative Research Actions (CRA), the IAI has championed integrative research that bridges scientific inquiry and policy action. The IAI’s Transdisciplinary Academy exemplifies this by offering hybrid training programs that empower researchers and policymakers with the tools to co-produce actionable knowledge. 

2. Strengthening Science-Policy Engagement: 

   The IAI's establishment of the Science Diplomacy Center (SDC) in 2023 and the Science, Technology and Policy (STeP) Fellowship have catalyzed science-policy engagement across the Americas through training programs, drafting of white papers and regional science-policy networks. These initiatives, notably the Panama Declaration on Science Diplomacy, underscore the IAI's role in shaping mechanisms of collaboration and fostering anticipatory science diplomacy, particularly related to climate change negotiations and environmental sustainability. 

3. Capacity Building and Regional Integration: 

The launch of the IAI Virtual Campus in 2023 has democratized access to specialized multilingual training in transdisciplinary research, science diplomacy, science communication, and climate-health interactions. Massive open virtual courses and in person trainings strengthened regional capacity and science-policy networks. Furthermore, strategic partnerships with U.S.-based organizations such as NOAA, NASA, USGCRP, AAAS, US National Academy of Science and global and regional institutions, such as the OAS, PAHO, WMO, CAF, IUCN, have reinforced regional scientific networks and knowledge exchange. 

4. Leadership in Global Science Diplomacy: 

   The IAI's active participation in international platforms —such as the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change, Convention on Biological Diversity, ISC and IPCC plenaries, and the Global Research Council highlight its leadership in elevating the voice of the Americas in the global scenario. These engagements have facilitated knowledge transfer and have positioned the IAI as a conduit for global-local policy integration.  

Broader Impacts and Societal Relevance: 

The IAI has focused on science-driven solutions addressing urgent environmental challenges. The IAI has played a lead role in crucial regional initiatives, such as the co-creation of early warning systems for health in the Caribbean and a new multinational proposal on Sargassum management to the Global Environment Facility. The IAI's commitment to equity, diversity, and inclusion (EDI), manifested through the creation and implementation of an EDI policy and the ongoing formation of advisory committees comprised of Indigenous Peoples and Local Communities, reflects its commitment to improve representation and participation in all its initiatives and programs. 

Future Directions: 

Looking ahead, the IAI's updated Strategic Plan (2024-2029) aims to deepen transdisciplinary collaboration, expand the Science Diplomacy Center's impact, and reinforce open data and open science practices to support evidence-based policymaking. Key upcoming initiatives include funding research teams through the Belmont Forum CRA on Tropical Forests, participating in the new Belmont Forum Oceans CRA, and expanding science diplomacy training in the region.  

The IAI's integrative model of transdisciplinary research, scientific and science diplomacy training is a model of regional cooperation on the most pressing global change issues. Its sustained efforts in funding research, embedding science into policy, training the next generation, and addressing environmental challenges will have an enduring impact on sustainable development trajectories in the Americas and beyond.
